thread.title: North Korean defector who worked at London embassy 'in hiding' in wake of Kim Jong-nam assassination
thread.title_full: North Korean defector who worked at London embassy 'in hiding' in wake of Kim Jong-nam assassination

author: Julian Ryall
title: North Korean defector who worked at London embassy 'in hiding' in wake of Kim Jong-nam assassination
text:
T he diplomat who defected from the North Korean embassy in London in July has gone into hiding in South Korea out of concern for his safety after the assassination of Kim Jong-nam in Malaysia on February 13.
South Korea's intelligence agency announced on Tuesday that Thae Yong-ho has cancelled all public activities, including media interviews, due to fears that he might be the next target of Pyongyang's agents, Yonhap news reported.
North Korea is known to have infiltrated agents into the South while state media has described Mr Thae as "human scum" and accused him of embezzling state funds, leaking state secrets, accepting bribes and raping a child.
Profile | Thae Yong-ho P yongyang will have been further enraged by Mr Thae claiming that the elite is turning against Kim Jong-un and predicting that the North Korean people will rise up to overthrow the dictator.
North Korea is also increasingly at loggerheads with the government of Malaysia, which has responded angrily to accusations that it is collaborating with nations that are hostile to North Korea and "has something to conceal".
Kim Jong-nam in Geneva S outh Korean legislators last week cited their spy agency as saying the young and unpredictable North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, had issued a "standing order" for his half-brother's assassination, and that there had been a failed attempt in 2012.
In a statement issued on Monday, the Malaysian foreign minister said comments made earlier in the day by Kang Chol, the North Korean ambassador to Kuala Lumpur, had been "culled from delusions, lies and half-truths".
Two of the women arrested in connection with the case A ny suggestion of a lack of impartiality "is deeply insulting to Malaysia, as is the suggestion that Malaysia is in collusion with any foreign government", the statement said, adding pointedly, "In all civilised nations, it is the norm for cases such as these to be comprehensively investigated".
On Monday, Mr Kang continued to pressure the Malaysian government for the remains of Kim Jong-nam, who was killed at Kuala Lumpur international airport earlier this month , to be handed over to diplomats representing Pyongyang.
Watch | Second arrest linked to the murder of Kim Jong-nam 01:15 H e also referred to the dead man as "Kim Chol," the name on the passport found with Kim Jong-nam.
Malaysian media has reported that the results of the autopsy conducted on Kim Jong-nam are to be announced on Wednesday.
Kim Jong-un | A history of executions - family, allies and rivals
